revisions.rev:
{{about|the characters of the TV series "Friends"|episodes of "Friends"|List of Friends episodes}} {{multiple issues|cleanup=September 2011| very long = September 2011| fanpov = September 2011| refimprove = June 2009}} [[File:Friends season one cast.jpg|thumb|250px|''Friends''{{'}} cast in the first season (1994), from left to right, [[Matt LeBlanc]] as [[Joey Tribbiani]], [[Lisa Kudrow]] as [[Phoebe Buffay]], [[Courteney Cox]] as [[Monica Geller]], [[Jennifer Aniston]] as [[Rachel Green]], [[David Schwimmer]] as [[Ross Geller]] and [[Matthew Perry (actor)|Matthew Perry]] as [[Chandler Bing]].]]
The American television sitcom ''[[Friends]]'' featured six main cast members throughout its run, with numerous '''characters''' recurring throughout the ten seasons. The main cast members were familiar to television viewers before their roles on ''Friends'', but were not considered to be stars.<ref name="friendsorigin"/><ref name="castnames">{{cite web|url=http://www.expressindia.com/news/fullstory.php?newsid=31095#compstory|title=''Friends'' heads for much-hyped farewell|accessdate=2008-12-19|date=2004-05-05|publisher=[[The Indian Express]]}}</ref> Series creator David Crane wanted all six characters to be equally prominent,<ref name="friendsorigin2">{{cite web |url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/topic/bal-friends-buzz0502,0,495484.story?page=2 |title=They leave as they began: With a buzz |pages=2|accessdate=23 December 2008|author=Jicha, Tom |date=May 2, 2004 |publisher=[[The Baltimore Sun]]}}</ref> and the series was lauded as being "the first true 'ensemble' show".<ref name="paidcasttog"/> The cast members made efforts to keep the ensemble format and not allow one member to dominate;<ref name="paidcasttog"/> they entered themselves in the same acting categories for awards,<ref name="community2003">{{cite web|url=http://www.usatoday.com/community/chat_03/2003-09-18-bianco.htm|title=The Emmy Awards: Robert Bianco |accessdate=19 December 2008|author=Bianco, Robert|date=January 1, 2005|publisher=[[USA Today]]}}</ref> opted for collective instead of individual salary negotiations,<ref name="paidcasttog">{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2004/0506/p01s01-ussc.html|title=A ''family'' sitcom for Gen X - ''Friends'' cast a new TV mold|accessdate=19 December 2008|author=McCarroll, Christina|date=May 6, 2004|publisher=[[The Christian Science Monitor]]}}</ref> and asked to appear together on magazine cover photos in the first season.<ref name="filmhours">{{cite web |url=http://www.enquirer.com/editions/2002/01/27/tem_friends_grows_in.html |title=''Friends'' grows in stature, ratings |accessdate=5 January 2009 |author=Kiesewetter, John |date=January 27, 2002 |publisher=[[The National Enquirer]]}}</ref> The cast members became best friends off screen,<ref name="kudrowcast">{{cite web|url=http://www.usaweekend.com/00_issues/001008/001008kudrow.html|title=Balancing friends and family |accessdate=19 December 2008|author=Zaslow, Jeffrey |date=October 8, 2000 |publisher=[[USA Weekend]]}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> and one [[Guest appearance|guest star]], [[Tom Selleck]], reported sometimes feeling left out.<ref>{{cite news|title=Why we will miss our absent ''Friends''|publisher=[[Irish Independent]]|date=May 6, 2004|author=Power, Ed|accessdate=19 December 2008}}</ref> The cast remained good friends after the series' run, most notably Cox and Aniston, with Aniston being godmother to Cox and [[David Arquette]]'s daughter, Coco.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denverpost.com/celebritybuzz/ci_7213047|title=People: DeGeneres tries to calm the howling pack|accessdate=19 December 2008|date=October 18, 2007|publisher=[[The Denver Post]]}}</ref> In the official farewell commemorative book ''[[Friends 'til the end (book)|Friends 'Til The End]]'', each separately acknowledged in his/her interview that the cast had become his/her family.<ref>{{cite book |title=Friends 'Til the End: The Official Celebration of All Ten Years |last=Wild |first=David |authorlink=David Wild |year=2004 |publisher=[[Time Warner]] |isbn=1932273190 |url=http://www.amazon.com/dp/1932273190 }}</ref>
In their original contracts for season one, each cast member was paid $22,500 per episode.<ref name="salariescastlots">{{cite web |url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/10164381.html?dids=10164381:10164381&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Aug+12%2C+1996&author=Lowry%2C+Brian&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=%27Friends%27+cast+returning+amid+contract+dispute&pqatl=google |title=''Friends'' cast returning amid contract dispute |accessdate=2009-03-08 |author=Lowry, Brian |date=August 12, 1996 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]]}}</ref> The cast members received different salaries in the second season, beginning from the $20,000 range to $40,000 per episode.<ref name="salariescastlots"/><ref name="castpaid">{{cite web |url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C03EED71E39F935A25754C0A960958260 |title=''Friends'' Cast Bands Together To Demand a Salary Increase |accessdate=2009-03-08 |author=Carter, Bill |date=July 16, 1996 |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> Prior to their salary negotiations for the third season, the cast decided to enter collective negotiations, despite Warner Bros. preference for individual deals.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,275935,00.html |title=Friendly Fire |accessdate=2009-03-08 |author=Rice, Lynette |date=April 21, 2000 |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |pages=1}}</ref> The actors were given the salary of the least paid cast member, meaning Aniston and Schwimmer had their salaries reduced. The stars were paid, per episode, $75,000 in the third season, $85,000 in the fourth, $100,000 in the fifth, and $125,000 in the sixth season.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,275935_2,00.html |title=Friendly Fire |accessdate=2009-03-08 |author=Rice, Lynette |date=April 21, 2000 |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |pages=2}}</ref> The cast members received salaries of $750,000 per episode in the seventh and eight seasons, and $1 million per episode in the ninth and tenth.<ref name="friendstimeline"/> The cast also received syndication royalties beginning with the fifth season.<ref name="castpaid"/>
==Main characters== All six main characters had prior experience in [[situation comedy]], and, in some cases, [[improvisational comedy]] as well. *'''[[Rachel Green|Rachel Karen Green]]''' ([[Jennifer Aniston]])âa fashion enthusiast and Monica's best friend from high school. Rachel and Ross Geller are involved in an on-off relationship throughout the series. Rachel's first job is a waitress at the coffee house [[Central Perk]], but she later becomes an assistant buyer at [[Bloomingdale's]], and a buyer at [[Polo Ralph Lauren]] in season five. Aniston had already appeared in several unsuccessful sitcom [[Television pilot|pilot]]s before being cast in ''Friends'';<ref name="friendsorigin"/> she was also on TV series ''[[Molloy (TV series)|Molloy]]'' and ''[[Ferris Bueller (TV series)|Ferris Bueller]]''âthe latter being based on the movie ''[[Ferris Bueller's Day Off]]''. After starring in the critically derided film ''[[Leprechaun (film)|Leprechaun]]'', she was prepared to give up acting when she auditioned for ''Friends''.
*'''[[Monica Geller-Bing|Monica Elizabeth Geller-Bing]]''' ([[Courteney Cox]])âthe mother hen of the group,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=PBPB&p_theme=pbpb&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAF87116FDB357D&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |title=Fall TV '94 |accessdate=2009-02-14 |author=Lomartire, Paul |date=September 4, 1994 |work=[[The Palm Beach Post]] |format=Registration required}}</ref> known for her [[obsessive-compulsive]] and competitive nature.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2004-03-03-revisiting-friends_x.htm |title=''Friends'' played great game of poker |accessdate=2009-02-20 |author=Bianco, Robert |date=March 3, 2004 |work=[[USA Today]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/article722553.ece |title=Sarey Carey: Does pride in housework make me bad as well as mad? |accessdate=2009-02-20 |date=May 21, 2006 |work=[[The Sunday Times]] | location=London}}</ref> Monica is often jokingly teased for having been an extremely overweight child by the others, especially her brother Ross. Monica is a chef who changes jobs often throughout the show, and marries longtime friend Chandler Bing in season seven. Cox had the highest profile career of the main actors when she was initially cast, having appeared in ''[[Ace Ventura: Pet Detective]]'' and ''[[Family Ties]]'',<ref name="friendsorigin"/> and having originally been discovered in a [[Bruce Springsteen]] video.
*'''[[Phoebe Buffay-Hannigan]]''' ([[Lisa Kudrow]])âan eccentric [[massage|masseuse]] and musician.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dawn.com/weekly/review/archive/040506/review1.htm |title=Six of the best |accessdate=2009-02-20 |author=Mangan, Lucy |date=May 6, 2004 |work=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]}} {{Dead link|date=November 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Phoebe became homeless at the age of 14, and is known for being ditzy yet street-smart.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/search/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1000632755 |title=Kudrow has ''Comeback''; Cox, HBO talk |accessdate=2009-02-20 |author=Andreeva, Nellie |date=September 20, 2004 |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Kudrow previously played waitress Ursula Buffay on ''[[Mad About You]]'', and reprised the dual role of twin sister Ursula as a recurring character during several episodes of ''Friends''.<ref name="friendsorigin">{{cite web |url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/topic/bal-friends-buzz0502,0,495484.story |title=They leave as they began: With a buzz |pages=1|accessdate=23 December 2008|author=Jicha, Tom |date=May 2, 2004 |publisher=[[The Baltimore Sun]]}}</ref> Prior to her acting career, Kudrow was an office manager and researcher for her father, a headache specialist; she also worked as a News Anchor/Reporter for [[KVII-TV]] in [[Amarillo, Texas]].<ref name="kudrowcast"/> Kudrow began her ''comedic'' career as a member of [[The Groundlings]], joining the ranks of those such as [[Will Ferrell]] and [[Janeane Garofalo]]. Briefly, Kudrow joined with [[Conan O'Brien]] and director [[Tim Hillman]] in the short-lived [[Improvisational theatre|improv]] troupe [[Unexpected Company]].<ref>[http://www.pxdrive.com/album/LISA+KUDROW_pictures_gyglpic/ Bio] at PX Drive.com</ref> She was also the only regular female member of the Transformers Comedy Troupe.<ref>[http://www.hollywoodauditions.com/Biographies/lisa_kudrow.htm Lisa Kudrow Biography] Hollywood Auditions.com</ref> Her improvisational work allowed her to invent a variety of [[impressionism|impression]] "characters"âsome of which were used in ''Friends''.{{Issue|date=November 2011}}
*'''[[Joey Tribbiani|Joseph "Joey" Francis Tribbiani]]''' ([[Matt LeBlanc]])âa struggling actor and food lover who becomes famous for his role on ''[[Days of our Lives]]'' as Dr. Drake Ramoray. Joey is a womanizer with many girlfriends throughout the series, and develops a crush on his friend Rachel in season eight. Before his role on ''Friends'', LeBlanc appeared as a regular on the short-lived ''[[TV 101]]'', a minor character in the sitcom ''[[Married... with Children]]'', and as a main character in its spin-offs, ''Top of the Heap'' and ''Vinnie & Bobby''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/topic/zap-ronleavittobit,0,4424382.story |title=''Married ... With Children'' Co-Creator Dies |accessdate=23 December 2008|author=McLellan, Dennis |date=February 12, 2008 |publisher=[[The Baltimore Sun]]}}</ref>
*'''[[Chandler Bing|Chandler Muriel Bing]]''' ([[Matthew Perry]])âan executive in [[statistical analysis]] and data reconfiguration for a large multi-national corporation. Chandler quits his job and becomes a junior [[copywriter]] at an advertising agency during season nine. Chandler is known for his sarcastic sense of humor,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=AC&p_theme=ac&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAEAB624D214A1B&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |title=''Friends'' Star Finally has Chance to Enjoy Success |accessdate=2009-02-20 |date=March 26, 1995 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]]}}</ref> and marries longtime friend Monica. Like Aniston, Perry had already appeared in several unsuccessful sitcom pilots before being cast.<ref name="friendstimeline">{{cite web|url=http://www.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2004-01-21-friends-timeline_x.htm|title=''Friends'' til the end|accessdate=19 December 2008|author=Saah, Nadia |date=January 21, 2004|publisher=[[USA Today]]}}</ref> He had also starred in the TV series ''[[Second Chance (TV series)|Second Chance]]'' and ''[[Sydney (TV series)|Sydney]]''.
*'''[[Ross Eustace Geller]]''', [[Ph.D.]] ([[David Schwimmer]])âa [[paleontology|paleontologist]] working at a museum of Prehistoric History, and later a [[professor]] of paleontology at [[New York University]]. Ross has three failed marriages during the series (including one that already ended before the pilot, and one with Rachel), and is involved in an on-off relationship with Rachel. Before being cast in ''Friends'', Schwimmer played minor characters in ''[[The Wonder Years]]'' and ''[[NYPD Blue]]'';<ref name="friendsorigin"/> his first regular series role was in the sitcom ''[[Monty (TV series)|Monty]]''. Schwimmer is the only cast member native to [[New York City]] in real life.
== Recurring characters, notable characters, and celebrity-played characters == Each of the following characters of ''Friends'' was: #played by a [[celebrity]], #particularly significant to the story of the series, and/or #recurring (appearing in two or more episodes).
===Introduced in season one=== [[File:Elliott Gould crop.jpg|thumb|[[Elliott Gould]] appeared in twenty episodes between 1994 and 2003 as Ross and Monica's father Jack Geller.]] *{{anchor|Jack Geller}}{{anchor|Judy Geller}}'''Jack''' and '''Judy Geller''' ([[Elliott Gould]] and [[Christina Pickles]])âRoss and Monica's parents. In early appearances, Jack frequently makes inappropriate comments, which he punctuates by exclaiming "I'm just ''saying''...!" Judy often makes condescending remarks about Monica's lack of a love life and sometimes forgets her daughter even exists, while simultaneously favoring Ross. :Pickles was nominated for the Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Guest Actress in a Comedy Series for her appearance in "The One Where Nana Dies Twice".<ref group="e" name="Nana">{{cite episode |title= The One Where Nana Dies Twice|credits= |airdate= September 10, 1994|season= 1|number= 8}}</ref> ''[[The Seattle Times]]'' ranked Jack and Judy jointly as the second best guest character of the series in 2004.<ref name="McFadden"/>
*{{anchor|Barry Farber}}'''Barry Farber''' ([[Mitchell Whitfield]])âRachel's jilted fiancÃ©. Barry, an orthodontist, decides to go on his and Rachel's honeymoon with her maid of honor Mindy, and soon begins a relationship with her. Their relationship hits a rough patch in "The One with the Evil Orthodontist"<ref group="e" name="Orthodontist">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Evil Orthodontist|credits= |airdate= April 6, 1995|season= 1|number= 20}}</ref> when he and Rachel consider getting back together. He decides to stay with Mindy and the two are married in "The One with Barry and Mindy's Wedding".<ref group="e" name="Barry and Mindy">{{cite episode |title= The One with Barry and Mindy's Wedding|credits= |airdate= May 16, 1996|season= 2|number= 24}}</ref> They are getting divorced by the time of "The One That Could Have Been, Part 1".<ref group="e" name="Could Have Been">{{cite episode |title= The One That Could Have Been|credits= |airdate= February 17, 2000|season= 6|number= 15}}</ref> Barry's last name is given as "Finkle" in the pilot and "Farber" in every other appearance, except in "The One with the Flashback" where he is referred to as "Barry Barber". He has also been called "Barry White". Possibly named as an homage to long-time NY talk show host, Barry Farber.
*{{anchors|Carol Willick|Susan Bunch}}'''Carol Willick''' ([[Anita Barone]] for character's debut episode, [[Jane Sibbett]] thereafter) and '''Susan Bunch''' ([[Jessica Hecht]])âRoss' lesbian ex-wife, who came out before the pilot, and her partner. Carol tells Ross that she is pregnant with his child in "The One with the Sonogram at the End"<ref group="e" name="Sonogram">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Sonogram at the End|credits= |airdate= October 29, 1994|season= 1|number= 2}}</ref> and is having it with her partner Susan. Susan does not attempt to hide her contempt of Ross and vice versa, but they briefly put aside their differences in "The One with the Birth"<ref group="e" name="Birth">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Birth |credits= |airdate= May 11, 1995|season= 1|number= 23}}</ref> when Carol gives birth to a boy, Ben. Carol and Susan get married in "[[The One with the Lesbian Wedding]]"<ref group="e" name="Lesbian Wedding">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Lesbian Wedding|credits= |airdate= January 19, 1996|season= 2|number= 11}}</ref> and make irregular appearances until "The One That Could Have Been, Part 2"<ref group="e" name="Could Have Been"/> (Susan) and "The One with the Truth About London"<ref group="e" name="Truth">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Truth About London|credits= |airdate= February 22, 2001|season= 7|number= 16}}</ref> (Carol).
:Carol and Susan were based on Marta Kauffman and David Crane's best friends in New York: "We didn't create them for any particular political reason or because of lesbian chic. It was just an opportunity to tell a really interesting story."<ref>Stallings (2000), p. 26.</ref> The characters were called a positive example of a gay couple on television by [[Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation|GLAAD]]. Jessica Hecht originally auditioned to play Monica.<ref>{{cite news |title=? |first=Bret |last=Watson |newspaper=Entertainment Weekly |date=December 1, 1995 |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,299751,00.html |accessdate=}}</ref>
*{{anchor|Gunther}}'''Gunther''' ([[James Michael Tyler]])âthe manager of the Central Perk coffee house, who first appears as a background character in "The One with the Thumb".<ref group="e" name="Thumb">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Thumb|credits= |airdate= October 6, 1994|season= 1|number= 3}}</ref> The character develops an unrequited crush on Rachel in the third season, which he keeps to himself until "[[The Last One (Friends)|The Last One]]".<ref group="e" name="Last One">{{cite episode |title= The Last One |credits= |airdate= May 6, 2004|season= 10|number= 17 & 18}}</ref> His jealousy of Ross is made clear numerous times, most notably in "The One the Morning After",<ref group="e" name="Morning After">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Morning After |credits= |airdate= February 20, 1997|season= 3|number= 16}}</ref> when he reveals to Rachel that Ross cheated on her when they were "on a break". Gunther appears in nearly every episode, but only occasionally calls attention to himself and almost never has a large role in the plot of an episode. In the Season 8 Episode "The One With The Stain", Gunther is shown to be fluent in [[Dutch language|Dutch]] (although with a hint of an American accent), calling Ross an ''[[donkey|ezel]]'' as he converses with him. (Ross is trying to learn Dutch in order to secure an apartment from a dying Dutch woman.) He also claimed to have played Bryce on ''[[All My Children]]'' and was "killed in an avalanche."
:James Michael Tyler was cast as Gunther because he was the only extra who could competently work the coffee machine on the Central Perk set. Tyler appears as Gunther in a co-host voice-over in the ''Friends'' trivia game for [[PlayStation 2|PS2]], PC and [[Xbox]], and in the board game ''Friends: Scene It?''. ''The Seattle Times'' ranked Gunther as the eighth best guest character of the series in 2004.<ref name="McFadden"/> When asked in 2009 by [[Heat (magazine)|Heatworld.com]] what Gunther would be doing "now", Tyler joked, "He'd probably have a very traditional marriage, with lots of white-haired babies running around with hair brighter than the sun."<ref>{{cite web|author=Staff |date= September 24, 2009|url= http://www.heatworld.com/Article/12312/Friends-/There-was-a-Friends-party-last-night-%E2%80%93-and-it-was-AMAZING|title= There was a Friends party last nightâand it was AMAZING!|publisher=Heatworld.com (Bauer Consumer Media)|accessdate= September 24, 2009}}</ref>
*'''Marcel''' ([[animals on television|live animal actor]])âa [[Capuchin monkey]] that Ross initially keeps as a pet<ref group="e" name="Monkey"/>, and who provides [[comic relief]] for his geeky master. One time Rachel loses him in the city<ref group="e" name="Monkey Gets Away"/>, and calls Animal Controlâonly to learn from Ross that Marcel is an illegal [[exotic animal]] that cannot be kept in the city. In order to keep the [[Animal control officer]]{{who|date=November 2011}}âa former classmate of Rachel's and Monica'sâfrom confiscating Marcel, Rachel threatens to tell the woman's boss about how she shot Phoebe "in the ass with a dart" that had been meant for Marcel. Later, as Marcel sexually matures and begins to hump everything, Ross has to give him away to a zoo{{Issue|date=November 2011}}â"where he can have access to regular monkey-lovin'." Ultimately, Ross finds out that Marcel then got stolen from the zoo and taken into a life of [[show business]], andâafter starring in a liquor commercialâis starring in a movie in New York<ref group="e" name="Superbowl">{{cite episode | title = The One After the Super Bowl | credits = | airdate = Jaunary 28, 1996 | season = 2 | number = 12 & 13}}</ref>, where they are reunited one last time.
*'''Drs. Michael Mitchell''' ([[George Clooney]]) and '''Jeffrey Rosen''' ([[Noah Wyle]])âtwo doctors that Rachel and Monica meet at a hospital, then go on a date with, pretending to be each other for insurance purposesâeventually causing things to go wild.<ref group="e" name="Two Parts" />
*'''[[Jill Goodacre]] Connick''' (herself)âgets trapped with Chandler in an [[Automatic teller machine|ATM]] vestibule in "The One with the Blackout".<ref group="e" name="Blackout">{{cite episode | title = The One With The Blackout | credits = | airdate = December 3, 1994 | season = 1 | number = 7}}</ref> Chandler uses his cell phone to tell Joey and the others, engages in awkward conversion with her, and finally lets her play a "spin the phone pen over your head" game with him.
*{{anchor|Janice Goralnik}}'''Janice Litman Goralnick''' ([[Maggie Wheeler]])âChandler's on-again off-again girlfriend for the first four seasons. Janice is one of the few characters besides the six main friends who appears in all of the ''Friends'' seasons. Chandler has trouble dumping her in "The One with the East German Laundry Detergent"<ref group="e" name="Uberweiss">{{cite episode |title= The One with the East German Laundry Detergent|credits= |airdate= October 20, 1994|season= 1|number= 5}}</ref> but gets back together with her for New Year's<ref group="e" name="Monkey">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Monkey|credits= |airdate= December 15, 1994|season= 1|number= 10}}</ref> and for Valentine's.<ref group="e" name="Candy Hearts">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Candy Hearts|credits= |airdate= February 9, 1995|season= 1|number= 14}}</ref> In "The One Where Mr. Heckles Dies",<ref group="e" name="Heckles Dies">{{cite episode |title= The One Where Mr. Heckles Dies|credits= |airdate= October 5, 1995|season= 2|number= 3}}</ref> Chandler is disappointed to discover that she is married and pregnant. In "The One with Barry and Mindy's Wedding",<ref group="e" name="Barry and Mindy"/> Chandler arranges a meeting with a mystery woman over the Internet, who turns out to be Janice. Their relationship lasts into the third season, when Janice decides to leave her husband to be with Chandler. Later, Joey sees Janice kissing her husband, who runs a mattress business.<ref group="e" name="Race Car">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Race Car Bed|credits= |airdate= November 7m 1996|season= 3|number= 7}}</ref> Chandler dumps her in "The One with the Giant Poking Device".<ref group="e" name="Poking">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Giant Poking Device|credits= |airdate= November 14, 1996|season= 3|number= 8}}</ref> When Janice returns to his life,<ref group="e" name="Rugby">{{cite episode |title= The One with All the Rugby|credits= |airdate= February 26,1996|season= 4|number= 15}}</ref> Chandler pretends to be moving to [[Yemen]]. She has a brief fling with Ross,<ref group="e" name="Work Laugh">{{cite episode |title= The One with Chandler's Work Laugh|credits= |airdate= January 21, 1999|season= 5|number= 12}}</ref> and makes a cameo on a "discovered" mix tape that Chandler plays for Monica, not knowing Janice's voice is on it.<ref group="e" name="Unagi">{{cite episode |title= The One with Unagi|credits= |airdate= February 24, 2000|season= 6|number= 17}}</ref> When Chandler and Monica become engaged, she tries to interfer with their wedding plansâleaving only when Monica says Chandler still loves her.<ref group="e" name="Library">{{cite episode |title= The One with Ross's Library Book|credits= |airdate= November 16, 2000|season= 7|number= 7}}</ref> In "The One Where Rachel Has a Baby",<ref group="e" name="Rachel Baby">{{cite episode |title= The One Where Rachel Has a Baby|credits= |airdate= May 16, 2002|season= 8|number= 23 & 24}}</ref> she is placed in the same labor room as Rachel at the hospital. She later gives birth to a son, Aaron, who she jokes will be Emma's future husband. As Monica and Chandler make plans to have children,<ref group="e" name="Fertility Test">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Fertility Test|credits= |airdate= May 1, 2003|season= 9|number= 21}}</ref> she offers Chandler advice and support at a fertility clinic. In "The One Where Estelle Dies",<ref group="e" name="Estelle Dies">{{cite episode |title= The One Where Estelle Dies |credits= |airdate= April 22, 2004|season= 10|number= 15}}</ref> she comes close to buying a house next door to the one Monica and Chandler want to buy. To get rid of her, Chandler pretends he still loves her.
:In "The One Where Estelle Dies",<ref group="e" name="Estelle Dies"/> Chandler gives her full name as Janice Litman Goralnick (nÃ©e Hosenstein). She spoke with a nasal New York accent and emphasized each word of her catchphrase "''Ohhh â myyy â God''!" Janice's distinctive laugh was borne out of a slip-up Wheeler made during the rehearsal of "The One with the East German Laundry Detergent";<ref group="e" name="Uberweiss"/> after Chandler and Janice's "More lattÃ©?"/"No, I'm still working on mine" lines, Wheeler laughed.<ref>Wheeler, Maggie (2004). ''Friends of Friends'' [DVD]. New Wave Entertainment DVD and Warner Home Entertainment.</ref> ''The Seattle Times'' ranked Janice as the best guest character of the series in 2004.<ref name="McFadden">{{cite news|author=McFadden, Kay|date=May 6, 2004|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/entertainment/2001920541_characters06.html|title=Friends of 'Friends': guest characters|work=The Seattle Times}}</ref>
*{{anchor|Mr. Heckles}}'''Mr. Heckles''' ([[Larry Hankin]])âMonica and Rachel's downstairs neighbor, an elderly man who constantly complains about the noise. He first appears in "The One with the Blackout",<ref group="e" name="Blackout"/> claiming to own a lost cat that Rachel has found. He appears again in "The One with Two Parts, Part 1"<ref group="e" name="Two Parts">{{cite episode |title= The One with Two Parts|credits= |airdate= February 23, 1995|season= 1|number= 16}}</ref> and "The One Where the Monkey Gets Away"<ref group="e" name="Monkey Gets Away">{{cite episode |title= The One Where the Monkey Gets Away|credits= |airdate= March 9, 1995|season= 1|number= 19}}</ref> before dying in "The One Where Mr. Heckles Dies".<ref group="e" name="Heckles Dies">{{cite episode |title= The One Where Mr. Heckles Dies|credits= |airdate= |season= |number= }}</ref> As a last spiteful act, he leaves all of his junk to "the noisy girls upstairs". He makes a final cameo appearance in "The One with the Flashback",<ref group="e" name="Flashback">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Flashback|credits= |airdate= October 31, 1996|season= 3|number= 6}}</ref> set in 1993, where he complains that Phoebe's noise is disturbing his oboe practice, and inadvertently causes Joey to be Chandler's roommate.
*{{anchor|Paolo}}'''Paolo''' ([[Cosimo Fusco]])âAn Italian neighbor in Monica's building, who Rachel falls for in "The One with the Blackout".<ref group="e" name="Blackout"/> They start dating, making Ross jealous. She dumps him after he gropes Phoebe<ref group="e" name="Lasagnas">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Dozen Lasagnas|credits= |airdate= January 12, 1995|season= 1|number= 12}}</ref> but has a last one-night stand with him in "The One with Ross's New Girlfriend".<ref group="e" name="Ross New Girlfriend">{{cite episode |title= The One with Ross's New Girlfriend|credits= |airdate= October 21, 1995|season= 2|number= 1}}</ref>
*{{anchor|Terry}}'''Terry''' ([[Max Wright]])âThe manager at Central Perk, who does not hide the fact that he thinks Rachel is a terrible waitressâand Phoebe is "''so'' bad" as a musician. He denies her an advance on her wages in "The One Where Underdog Gets Away"<ref group="e" name="Underdog">{{cite episode |title= The One Where Underdog Gets Away |credits= |airdate= November 17, 1994|season= 1|number= 9}}</ref> and hires a professional musician, '''Stephanie''' ([[Chrissie Hynde]] of [[The Pretenders]]), to replace Phoebe in "The One with the Baby on the Bus".<ref group="e" name="Bus">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Baby on the Bus|credits= |airdate= November 2, 1995|season= 2|number= 6}}</ref>
*{{anchor|Fun Bobby}}'''"Fun Bobby" (Robert)''' ([[Vincent Ventresca]])âA boyfriend of Monica's. In his first appearance in "The One with the Monkey",<ref group="e" name="Monkey"/> his "fun" is sapped at Monica's New Year's party after his grandfather died. In "The One with Russ",<ref group="e" name="Russ">{{cite episode |title= The One with Russ |credits= |airdate= January 4, 1996|season= 2|number= 10}}</ref> the gang discovers that alcohol puts the "fun" into Fun Bobby. Monica tries to wean him off drinking but regrets it when he becomes extremely boring. It is revealed in the episode "The One with Phoebe's Husband" that the underwear on the telephone pole was Monica's when she was having sex with Fun Bobby on the terrace. [[File:Hankazaria05.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Hank Azaria]] first played David, the love of Phoebe's life, in 1994. He made several recurring appearances between 2001 and 2003.]] *{{anchor|David}}'''David''', "the Scientist Guy" ([[Hank Azaria]])âA physicist whom Phoebe falls in love with in "The One with the Monkey".<ref group="e" name="Monkey"/> After a fight with his research partner Max (Wayne PÃ©re), David decides to go on a research trip to [[Minsk]] with him, breaking Phoebe's heart. He returns to New York for a brief visit<ref group="e" name="Cheesecakes">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Cheesecakes|credits= |airdate= January 4, 2001|season= 7|number= 11}}</ref> and shares an evening with Phoebe. He returns permanently in "The One with the Male Nanny"<ref group="e" name="Male Nanny">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Male Nanny|credits= |airdate= November 7, 2002|season= 9|number= 6}}</ref> and he and Phoebe resume their relationship in "The One with the Donor".<ref group="e" name="Donor">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Donor|credits= |airdate= May 8, 2003|season= 9|number= 22}}</ref> In "[[Friends (season 9)|The One in BarbadosâPart 1]]",<ref group="e" name="Barbados">{{cite episode |title= The One in Barbados |credits= |airdate= May 15, 2003|season= 9|number= 23}}</ref> David proposes to Phoebe. She turns him down and gets back together with Mike, and David leaves.
:In 2003, Azaria was nominated for the [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Guest Actor in a Comedy Series]] for his performance.
*{{anchor|Nora Tyler Bing}}'''Nora Tyler Bing''' ([[Morgan Fairchild]])âChandler's mother, an erotic novelist. She first appears in "The One with Mrs. Bing",<ref group="e" name="Mrs Bing">{{cite episode |title= The One with Mrs. Bing |credits= |airdate= January 1, 1995|season= 1|number= 11}}</ref> where she meets the gang while on a book tour in New York. After dinner, she kisses Ross. She makes a cameo appearance in the flashback scenes of "[[The One with All the Thanksgivings]]"<ref group="e" name="Thanksgiving Flashback">{{cite episode |title= The One with All the Thanksgivings|credits= |airdate= November 19, 1998|season= 5|number= 8}}</ref> and later appears in "[[The One with Chandler and Monica's Wedding]]" (with [[Kathleen Turner]] as Chandler's dad)<ref group="e" name="M and C Wedding">{{cite episode |title= The One with Chandler and Monica's Wedding|credits= |airdate= May 17, 2001|season= 7|number= 23 & 24}}</ref> and "The One After 'I Do'".<ref group="e" name="I Do">{{cite episode |title= The One After "I Do"|credits= |airdate= September 27, 2001|season= 8|number= 1}}</ref> ''The Seattle Times'' ranked Nora and her ex-husband jointly as the fifth best guest characters in 2004.<ref name="McFadden"/>
*{{anchor|Ursula Buffay}}'''Ursula Pamela Buffay''' ([[Lisa Kudrow]])âPhoebe's identical twin. Kudrow originated the role of Ursula in the sitcom ''[[Mad About You]]'', playing her as an inept waitress at Riff's who frequently forgets orders.<ref group="e">{{cite episode|title=Married to the Job|credits=Russ Woody (writer); [[Thomas Schlamme]] (director)|series=[[Mad About You]]|network=NBC|airdate=October 7, 1993|season=2|number=4}}</ref> She first appears in ''Friends'' in "The One with Two Parts":<ref group="e" name="Two Parts"/> Chandler and Joey are eating at Riff's and mistake Ursula for Phoebe. Joey becomes attracted to Ursula and they start dating. Ursula tells Phoebe that she is bored with Joey, so Phoebe pretends to be her sister to let Joey down gently. In the same episode, [[Helen Hunt]] and [[Leila Kenzle]] cameo as their ''[[Mad About You]]'' characters [[Jamie Buchman]] and [[Fran Devanow]], in a scene where they mistake Phoebe for Ursula in Central Perk. Ursula next appears briefly in "The One with the Jam",<ref group="e" name="Jam">{{cite episode|title=The One with the Jam|credits=|airdate=October 3, 1996|season=3|number=3}}</ref> where she is being stalked by a man ([[David Arquette]]) who mistakes Phoebe for her. In "The One with the Jellyfish"<ref group="e" name="Jellyfish">{{cite episode|title=The One with the Jellyfish|credits=|airdate=September 25, 1997|season=4|number=1}}</ref> Phoebe tells Ursula that she has met their birth mother, but Ursula already knows about her. In "The One Where Chandler Can't Cry",<ref group="e" name="Cry">{{cite episode|title=The One Where Chandler Can't Cry|credits=|airdate=February 10, 2000|season=6|number=14}}</ref> Phoebe starts getting unwanted attention from men, and discovers that Ursula is starring in pornographic films using Phoebe's name. Phoebe gets revenge by claiming Ursula's fees and embarrassing her many male fans. Flashbacks in "The One Where They All Turn Thirty"<ref group="e" name="Thirty">{{cite episode|title=The One Where They All Turn Thirty|credits=|airdate=February 8, 2001|season=7|number=14}}</ref> reveal that Ursula sold Phoebe's birth certificate to a Swedish runaway, and that both sisters are ''31'', not 30. In "The One with the Halloween Party",<ref group="e" name="Halloween">{{cite episode|title=The One with the Halloween Party|credits=|airdate=November 1, 2001|season=8|number=6}}</ref> Ursula introduces Phoebe to Eric ([[Sean Penn]]), her fiancÃ©. Phoebe is horrified that Ursula has told Eric that she is a teacher, a member of the [[Peace Corps]], a non-smoker, and attends a church group (all lies). The series finale of ''Mad About You'', set 22 years into the future, reveals that after a successful porn career, Ursula becomes [[Governor of New York]].<ref group="e">{{cite episode|title=The Final Frontier|credits=[[Paul Reiser]], [[Helen Hunt]] (writers); Helen Hunt (director)|series=[[Mad About You]]|network=NBC|airdate=May 24, 1999|season=7|number=21}}</ref>
*{{anchor|Mindy}}'''Mindy''' ([[Jennifer Grey]] in "The One with the Evil Orthodontist",<ref group="e" name="Orthodontist"/> [[Jana Marie Hupp]] in "The One with Barry and Mindy's Wedding"<ref group="e" name="Barry and Mindy"/>)âRachel's maid of honor at her aborted wedding to Barry. Mindy and Rachel were best friends while growing up and their friendship is tested after Rachel discovers Mindy and Barry are seeing each other. She asks Rachel to be her maid of honor and dress in a garish pink dress. Mindy marries Barry in "The One with Barry and Mindy's Wedding",<ref group="e" name="Barry and Mindy"/> becoming Mindy Hunter-Farber. They are getting divorced by "The One That Could Have Been, Part 1".<ref group="e" name="Could Have Been"/>
*'''Lydia''' ([[Leah Remini]])âa single mother-to-be whose childbirth Joey assists before going to see Carol give birth to Ben.<ref group="e" name="Birth"/> Remini had originally auditioned for the role of Monica.
*{{anchor|Ben}}'''Ben''' (Various actors, 1995â1999; [[Cole Sprouse]], 2000â2002)âRoss and Carol's son, born during "The One with the Birth".<ref group="e" name="Birth"/> Ben is played as an infant by Michael Gunderson, by brothers Charles Thomas Allen and John Christoper Allen from Season 3 to 5, and by Cole Sprouse from Season 6 to 8. Kay McFadden of ''The Seattle Times'' ranked Ben as her least favorite guest character of the series in 2004.<ref name="McFadden"/>
*{{anchor|Julie}}'''Julie''' ([[Lauren Tom]])âAn old graduate school colleague of Ross', whom he meets again while on a trip to [[China]] in "The One Where Rachel Finds Out".<ref group="e" name="Rachel Finds">{{cite episode |title= The One Where Rachel Finds Out|credits= |airdate= May 18, 1995|season= 1|number= 24}}</ref> They start dating but break up in "The One with the List"<ref group="e" name="List">{{cite episode |title= The One with the List|credits= |airdate= November 16, 1995|season= 2|number= 8}}</ref> when Ross reveals he loves Rachel. She makes a final cameo in the tag scene of "The One with Russ",<ref group="e" name="Russ"/> where she falls in love with a Ross lookalike.
=== Introduced in season two === *{{anchor|Mr. Treeger}}'''Mr. Treeger''' ([[Michael G. Hagerty]])âThe superintendent of Monica's building. Treeger first appears in "The One Where Heckles Dies",<ref group="e" name="Heckles Dies"/> where he shows Heckles's lawyer where Monica and Rachel live. He next appears in "The One with Phoebe's Dad",<ref group="e" name="Phoebe's Dad">{{cite episode |title= The One with Phoebe's Dad|credits= |airdate= December 14, 1995|season= 2|number= 9}}</ref> where Monica thinks he is playing hardball by not mending her broken radiator. In "The One with the Ballroom Dancing",<ref group="e" name="Ballroom">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Ballroom Dancing |credits= |airdate= October 16, 1997|season= 4|number= 4}}</ref> he threatens to have Monica and Rachel evicted unless Joey helps him practice ballroom dancing to impress a woman. In "The One with the Free Porn",<ref group="e" name="Porn">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Free Porn|credits= |airdate= March 26, 1998|season= 4|number= 17}}</ref> he cleans the shower drain of Chandler and Joey's newly-won apartment, and warns them never to turn off their TV after they start receiving free porn. In his final appearance in "The One Where Rachel Tells...",<ref group="e" name="Rachel Tells">{{cite episode |title= The One Where Rachel Tells...|credits= |airdate= October 11, 2001|season= 8|number= 3}}</ref> he has a fireman break down the door to Monica's apartment after Joey tells him he smelled gas.
*'''Caroline Duffy''' ([[Lea Thompson]])âreprising her role from ''[[Caroline in the City]]'', she talks with Joey and Chandlerâseeing them with Ben and consequently thinking them to be loversâin "The One with the Baby on the Bus".<ref group="e" name="Bus" />
*{{anchor|Estelle Leonard}}'''Estelle Leonard''' ([[June Gable]])âJoey's talent agent. Gable made her first appearance as Estelle in "The One with the Butt",<ref group="e" name="Butt">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Butt|credits= |airdate= October 27, 1994|season= 1|number= 5}}</ref> but the scene was cut for timing reasons although it is included in the DVD version of season 1 (she is still mentioned after Joey's play in the original episode that aired). She makes her first proper appearance in "The One with Russ",<ref group="e" name="Russ"/> when, after Joey tells he is fed up of poor roles, she gets him a recurring part in ''[[Days of Our Lives]]''. She is shown to be supportive of Joey's career in "The One with the Screamer"<ref group="e" name="Screamer">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Screamer|credits= |airdate= April 24, 1997|season= 3|number= 22}}</ref> but willfully sabotages<ref group="e" name="Insurance">{{cite episode |title= The One Where Joey Loses His Insurance|credits= |airdate= OCtober 14, 1999|season= 6|number= 4}}</ref> after she thinks Joey had left her. She dies in the last season;<ref group="e" name="Estelle Dies"/> Joey gives a speech at her memorial service, where it is revealed that her only other client is Al Zebooker, a man who eats paper.
:When Gable auditioned for the role, she played Estelle quite plainly and was encouraged to "go away and do something with her". She returned to the audition room wearing a "fat suit" and eating a sandwich from a delicatessen, which she stubbed out a cigarette on. The performance was used in the deleted scene of "The One with the Butt".<ref group="e" name="Butt"/> Her age is never given but Gable believed that she was in her 80s.<ref>Gable, June (2004). ''Friends of Friends'' [DVD]. New Wave Entertainment DVD and Warner Home Entertainment.</ref> In 2004, ''The Seattle Times'' ranked Estelle as the sixth best guest character of the series.<ref name="McFadden"/> Gable also plays the nurse who delivers Ben in "The One with the Birth".
[[File:Selleck1.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Tom Selleck]] played Monica's boyfriend (and later Chandler's nemesis) Dr. Richard Burke in several episodes between 1995 and 2000.]] *{{anchor|Richard Burke}}'''Richard Burke''' ([[Tom Selleck]])âAn [[ophthalmologist]] and best friend of Jack Geller. Richard is introduced in "The One Where Ross and Rachel â¦ You Know"<ref group="e" name="You Know">{{cite episode |title= The One Where Ross and Rachel ... You Know|credits= |airdate= February 8, 1996|season= 2|number= 16}}</ref> when Monica caters an event at his apartment. He and Monica soon start seeing each other, infuriating Monica's parents when they find out.<ref group="e" name="Joey Moves">{{cite episode |title= The One Where Joey Moves Out|credits= |airdate= February 15, 1996|season= 2|number= 17}}</ref> He and Monica break up in "The One with Barry and Mindy's Wedding"<ref group="e" name="Barry and Mindy"/> when he tells her he does not want more children, his own having already reached adulthood. Despite the two still being in love, they cannot reconcile this difference, and are both devastated for months. He makes a brief voice cameo in "[[The One Where No One's Ready]]"<ref group="e" name="Ready">{{cite episode |title= The One Where No One's Ready |credits= |airdate= September 26, 1996|season= 3|number= 2}}</ref>, and later they briefly attempt to rekindle their romance as "friends"<ref group="e" name="Just Friends">{{cite episode |title= The One Where Monica and Richard Are Just Friends|credits= |airdate= January 30, 1997|season= 3|number= 13}}</ref>. In "[[The One with the Proposal]]",<ref group="e" name="Proposal">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Proposal|credits= |airdate= May 18, 2000|season= 6|number=24 & 25}}</ref> he proposes to Monica after she leaves Chandler, who's planning to propose but pretends to be against marriage because he "wants it to be a surprise". After Chandler comes to his apartment searching for Monica and tells Richard of his own proposal plan, Richard tells Chandler, "You go ''get'' her, Chandler. And take my advice: If you ''do'' get her, ''don't'' let her go." His apartment is put up for sale in Season 9, in "The One with Ross's Inappropriate Song", but Richard is not seen.
:All of Selleck's entrances in Season 2 had to be refilmed after the audience left because "it was like The Beatles with the screaming and the applause".<ref>Stallings (2000), p. 53.</ref> For his appearance in "The One with the Proposal",<ref group="e" name="Proposal"/> Selleck was nominated for the Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Guest Actor in a Comedy Series. In 2004, ''The Seattle Times'' ranked Richard as the third best guest character of the series.<ref name="McFadden"/>
*{{anchor|Sandra Green}}'''Sandra Green''' ([[Marlo Thomas]])âRachel's mother. In "The One with the Lesbian Wedding"<ref group="e" name="Lesbian Wedding"/> she announces to Rachel that she never loved Rachel's father ("You didn't marry your Barry, but ''I'' married ''mine''.") and is divorcing him. She later accompanies everyone to Carol and Susan's wedding. In "The One with Two Parties"<ref group="e" name="Parties">{{cite episode |title= The One with Two Parties|credits= |airdate= May 2, 1996|season=2 |number= 22}}</ref> she arrives at Rachel's birthday party and is unaware for the whole night that her ex-husband is also there. In "The One with the Baby Shower"<ref group="e" name="Shower">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Baby Shower|credits= |airdate= April 25, 2002|season= 8|number= 20}}</ref> she decides to move in with Ross and Rachel to help with the baby's first months but Ross changes her mind.
:For her appearance in "The One with the Lesbian Wedding", Thomas was nominated for the Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Guest Actress in a Comedy Series.
*{{anchor|Eddie Menuek}}'''Eddie Menuek''' ([[Adam Goldberg]])âAfter Joey, having landed the recurring role Dr. [[Drake Ramoray]] on ''[[Days of our Lives]]'', moves into his own apartment<ref group="e" name="Joey Moves"/>, Chandler gets a new roommate.<ref group="e" name="Eddie Moves">{{cite episode |title= The One Where Eddie Moves In|credits= |airdate= February 22, 1996|season= 2|number= 17}}</ref> Eddie and Chandler have nothing in common; Eddie hates ''Baywatch'', foosball, and sports in general, and likes to steal mannequins from [[Macy's]] and dehydrate fruit. In "The One Where Dr. Ramoray Dies",<ref group="e" name="Ramoray">{{cite episode |title= The One Where Dr. Ramoray Dies|credits= |airdate= March 21, 1996|season= 2|number= 18}}</ref> he suspects Chandler of both having sex with his ex-girlfriend Tilly and killing his goldfish, so spites him by stealing his insoles. Later he forgets these events, but Chandler wants him out after learning that Eddie watches him sleep.<ref group="e" name="Eddie Go">{{cite episode |title= The One Where Eddie Won't Go|credits= |airdate= March 28, 1996|season= 2|number= 19}}</ref> Eddie agrees to leave but later denies the conversation took place; so Chandler allows Joey to move back in; they move his stuff out into the hall and pretend they have never met him. Eddie falls for their bluff and leaves.
:Adam Goldberg later appeared in the second season of ''Joey'' as a different character.
*{{anchor|Frances Buffay}}'''Frances Buffay''' ([[Audra Lindley]])âPhoebe's grandmother. Her only appearance is in "The One with Phoebe's Dad",<ref group="e" name="Phoebe's Dad">{{cite episode |title= The One with Phoebe's Dad|credits= |airdate= |season= |number= }}</ref>, where she reveals to Phoebe that the person in the pictures she keeps around the house is not Phoebe's father, which motivates Phoebe to try and track down her real father. Though the character appears in only one episode, she is mentioned in a few more, including in season 5's "The One with Joey's Bag",<ref group="e" name="The One with Joey's Bag">{{cite episode |title= The One with Joey's Bag|credits= |airdate= February 4, 1999|season= 5|number= 13}}</ref> where it is revealed that she has recently passed away and Phoebe plans her funeral. Phoebe inherits her grandmother's yellow taxi and apartment. She keeps the taxi until the very end of the series.
*{{anchor|Frank Buffay, Jr.}}'''Frank Buffay, Jr.''' ([[Giovanni Ribisi]])âPhoebe's half brother by their father. In "The One with the Bullies"<ref group="e" name="Bullies">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Bullies|credits= |airdate= April 25, 1996|season= 2|number= 21}}</ref> Phoebe meets him after finding the courage to knock on her father's suburban door, but discovers he walked out several years ago. Frank later visits the city<ref group="e" name="Frank Jr">{{cite episode |title= The One with Frank Jr.|credits= |airdate= October 17, 1996|season= 3|number= 5}}</ref> where he hits on Jasmine, one of Phoebe's coworkers, and mistakes her massage parlor for a whorehouse. He eventually falls in love with and becomes engaged to '''Alice Knight''' {{anchor|Alice Knight}}([[Debra Jo Rupp]]), his old home economics teacher who is 26 years his senior.<ref group="e" name="Hypnosis">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Hypnosis Tape|credits= |airdate= March 13, 1997|season= 3|number= 18}}</ref> In "The One with Phoebe's Uterus",<ref group="e" name="Uterus">{{cite episode |title= The One with Phoebe's Uterus|credits= |airdate= January 8, 1998|season= 4|number= 11}}</ref> they ask Phoebe to be a surrogate mother to their child, which turns out to be triplets in "The One Hundredth."<ref group="e" name="Hundredth">{{cite episode |title= The One Hundredth|credits= |airdate= October 8, 1998|season= 5|number= 3}}</ref> Frank makes a final appearance in "The One Where Ross is Fine",<ref group="e" name="Ross Fine">{{cite episode |title= The One Where Ross is Fine|credits= |airdate= October 2, 2003|season= 10|number= 2}}</ref> when he and the triplets meet Phoebe at Central Perk.
:Previously, Ribisi appeared in "The One with the Baby on the Bus" as a stranger who leaves a condom rather than money in Phoebe's guitar case when she is singing in the street, and then comes back to retrieve it. It was never addressed if this was intended to be the same character as Frank, who had not yet been introduced by name. <ref group="e" name="Bus">{{cite episode |title= The One With the Baby on the Bus|credits= |airdate= November 2, 1995|season= 2|number= 6}}</ref>
:In 2004, ''The Seattle Times'' ranked Frank as the fourth best guest character of the series.<ref name="McFadden"/> Alice was only scheduled to appear in the one episode but was brought back for a recurring role after the surrogacy storylineâwhich was created when Lisa Kudrow became pregnant in real life.<ref>Jo Rupp, Debra (2004). ''Friends of Friends'' [DVD]. New Wave Entertainment DVD and Warner Home Entertainment.</ref>
*{{anchor|Leonard Green}}'''Leonard Green''' ([[Ron Leibman]])âRachel's father, a vascular surgeon who takes an instant dislike to her boyfriend Ross.<ref group="e" name="Parties"/> Later, when Ross and Rachel conceive a child (Emma), he becomes furious that they're not engaged<ref group="e" name="Stripper">{{cite episode| title=The One with the Stripper| credits=| airdate=November 15, 2001| season=8| number=8}}</ref> He has a heart attack in "The One Where Joey Speaks French"<ref group="e" name="French">{{cite episode |title= The One Where Joey Speaks French|credits= |airdate= February 19, 2004|season= 10|number= 15}}</ref> and is recovering in the hospital when Ross turns up.
*{{anchor|Susie Moss}}'''Susie "Underpants" Moss''' ([[Julia Roberts]])âChandler (Matthew Perry) meets his old childhood friend Susie, who's working on the production of a movie<ref group="e" name="Superbowl"/>, and with whom Chandler has a colored history: when they were in elementary school, Chandler pulled up Susie's skirt when she was on stage, revealing her underwear to the entire school. They arrange a date, Chandler unsuspecting that it is a plot to get revenge. After convincing him to wear her panties, Susie leaves him wearing nothing but the panties in a bathroom stall in the restaurant where they were having dinner.
*{{anchor|Jean Claude Van Damme}} '''[[Jean Claude Van Damme]]''' (himself)âRachel and Monica compete for his attention. This creates tension between them, as they both argue over who should get to date him. They both dump him when he tries to convince them to have a threesome with Drew Barrymore.<ref group="e" name="Superbowl"/>
*{{anchor|Erika}}'''Erika''' ([[Brooke Shields]])âJoey has to contend with a stalker who thinks that Joey is actually Dr. Drake Ramoray, the character he plays on ''Days of our Lives''.{{Issue|date=November 2011}} Despite this, Joey goes on a date with her. She dumps him when she suspects "Drake" is cheating on her with another woman (actually another character in the soap opera). He tries to explain that "It's a TV show!" and "I'm not ''Drake!''", but she doesn't understand, so Ross tells her Joey's "Hans Ramoray", Drake's "evil twin"âand Joey tells her to go to Salem to find the "real" Drake Ramoray.
*{{anchor|Zoo administrator}}'''Zoo Administrator''' ([[Fred Willard]])âof the zoo Ross sent Marcel to after Marcel started humping everything. He informs Ross that Marcel has died. The {{anchor|Zoo janitor}}'''Zoo Janitor''' ([[Dan Castelanetta]]), however, later informs Ross that Marcel was in fact kidnapped and forced into show business, and is currently filming a movie in New York.<ref group="e" name="Superbowl" />
*{{anchor|Rob Donnan}}'''Rob Donnan''' ([[Chris Isaak]])âRob asks Phoebe to sing for the children at a library, but their parents are horrified by her morbid lyrics. However, the kids like the songs and come to the cafÃ© to listen to her.{{Issue|date=November 2011}}
*{{anchor|Ryan}}'''Ryan''' ([[Charlie Sheen]])âRyan arrives in New York on leave from the Navy to see Phoebe, who has chicken pox.<ref group="e" name="Pox">{{cite episode| title=The One with the Chicken Pox| credits=| airdate=May 5, 1996| season=2| number=23}}</ref> Even though he hasn't yet had chicken pox, he can't stand to be apart and they both spend the rest of the time sick and trying to not scratch at the sores.
=== Introduced in season three === *<span id="Mark Robinson"/>'''Mark Robinson''' ([[Steven Eckholdt]])âRachel's deskmate at [[Bloomingdale's]], who first appears in "The One Where Chandler Can't Remember Which Sister" (airdate January 9, 1997; Season 3, No. 11). Ross is jealous of Mark as he suspects that he and Rachel are having an affair. It is Mark's presence at Rachel's apartment after she fought with Ross which leads Ross to sleep with Chloe<ref group="e" name="Break">{{cite episode|title=The One where Ross and Rachel Take a Break|credits=|airdate=January 1, 1997|season=3|number=15}}</ref> ultimately ending Ross and Rachel's relationship. Later, Mark asks Rachel on a date and she accepts, however she rejects his advances when she realizes she only accepted the offer to get back at Ross.<ref group="e" name="Tiny T-shirt">{{cite episode|title=The One with the Tiny T-Shirt|credits=|airdate=March 27, 1997|season=3|number=19}}</ref> That is the last time Mark is seen until "The One with Princess Consuela"<ref group="e" name="Consuela"/>, where he informs Rachel of a job in Paris. Ross fails to recognize him but becomes jealous all over again once reminded.
*<span id="Sophie"/>'''Sophie''' ([[Laura Dean]])âMark's replacement. Sophie is frequently victimized by her boss Joanna. In the episode "The One Where They're Going to Party" (airdate December 11, 1997; Season 4, No. 9), she is estatic about Joanna's death.
*<span id="Chloe"/>'''Chloe''' ([[Angela Featherstone]])â"The girl from the copy place" who Ross sleeps with in when Ross and Rachel are supposedly "on a break."<ref group="e" name="Break"/>. She is mentioned twice in "The One with the Jam". Ross quickly tries to usher her out of his apartment in "The One with the Morning After". [[File:JonFavreauScreenTXMarch09.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Jon Favreau]] played Monica's entrepreneur and ultimate fighting boyfriend Pete Becker in six episodes of Season 3.]] *<span id="Peter Becker"/>'''Pete Becker''' ([[Jon Favreau]])âA computer software genius and multi-millionaire. Pete tips Monica $20,000 at the Moondance diner in "The One with the Hypnosis Tape", which she assumes is a joke. He asks her out on a date and takes her to [[Rome]]. They start seeing each other but initially break up Monica isn't attracted to him. They reconcile after Monica kisses him when he offers her a job in his restaurant (which she turns down), and realizes that she is attracted to him after all. Monica thinks he is going to propose in "The One with Ross's Thing" (airdate May 1, 1997; Season 3, No. 23); instead, he tells her he wants to become the [[Ultimate Fighting Champion]]. He gets badly beaten<ref group="e" name="UFC">{{cite episode|title=The One with the Ultimate Fighting Champion|credits=|airdate=May 8, 1997|number=3}}</ref>, and Monica ends it with him after he refuses to quit.
:The character of Pete was conceived as "a [[Bill Gates]] billionaire genius scientist-type" whom Monica was not attracted to. The producers and casting director had difficulty finding an actor to play Pete as they wanted, "someone who was appealing enough that we liked him, so we could root for him, but on the other hand, wasn't so drop-dead male model gorgeous that we would go, 'What's your problem?' to Monica when she didn't fall for him."<ref>Stallings (2000), p. 92.</ref>
*<span id="Kate Miller"/>'''Kate Miller''' ([[Dina Meyer]])âJoey's co-star in a play.<ref group="e" name="Tiny T-shirt"/> Joey falls for her but she fails to see any attraction in him and is already dating the director. The play turns out to be dismal, and after the director dumps her she gets together with Joey in "The One with the Screamer". Joey is distraught when she leaves for a soap opera role in Los Angeles. In the episode "The One in Barbados (1)", Joey and Rachel, in hope of getting into the Pharmaceutical convention, use [[Identity document forgery|fake IDs]] in which one of the names is "Kate Miller".
*<span id="Joanna"/>'''Joanna''' ([[Alison LaPlaca]])âRachel's boss, who dates Chandler in "The One with the Dollhouse" (airdate April 10, 1997; Season 3, No. 20) and "The One with the Cuffs" (airdate October 9, 1997; Season 4, No. 3). She is hostile to her assistant, Sophie, but good-natured towards Rachel. She offers Rachel a promotion in "The One Where They're Going to Party!" but is knocked down and killed by a cab before she can effect it.
*<span id="Doug"/>'''Douglas "Doug"''' ([[Sam McMurray]])âChandler's new boss in "The One with the Ultimate Fighting Champion"<ref group="e" name="UFC"/>. Doug enjoys calling Chandler "''Bing!''" and slapping his male colleagues on the butt. Monica and Chandler try to compete with Doug and his wife in "The One with Chandler's Work Laugh" (January 21, 1999; Season 5, No. 12). In "The One with Ross's Step Forward" (airdate December 13; 2001; Season 8, No. 11), he invites Monica and Chandler to dinner to celebrate his divorce. To get out of it, Chandler pretends that he and Monica have split up but it backfires when Doug tries to cheer him up by taking him to strip clubs, throwing cans at birds and throwing his wedding ring into the gutter.
*<span id="Tomas"/>'''Tomas''' ([[Robin Williams]]) and <span id="Tim"/>'''Tim''' ([[Billy Crystal]])âAppearing at the beginning of "The One with the Ultimate Fighting Champion", they perform an otherwise pointless cameo/skit performance while sitting on the group's sofa at Central Perk. They are not mentioned in the credits. Tomas begins by asking the friends to move over to make room for the pair which they do. Then Tomas complains to Tim about how he thinks his wife is cheating on him with her gynaecologist. The friends stop trying to have their own conversation and eavesdrop. Eventually Tim reveals how he's sleeping with Williams' wife causing him to leave in a loud fury.
*<span id="Bonnie"/>'''Bonnie''' ([[Christine Taylor]])âPhoebe's friend who she sets up with Ross in "The One with the Ultimate Fighting Champion". Rachel met Bonnie two years before and still thinks she is bald. She is not, so to spite her, Rachel convinces her to shave her hair off again in "The One at the Beach" (airdate May 15, 1997; Season 3, No. 25). She makes a brief appearance at the beginning of "The One with the Jellyfish", when Ross decides to dump her and get back together with Rachel. [[File:Teri Garr at the AIDS Project Los Angeles (APLA) benefit cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Teri Garr]] played Phoebe's birth mother, Phoebe Abbott, in three episodes of Seasons 3 and 4.]] *<span id="Phoebe Abbott"/>'''Phoebe Abbott''' ([[Teri Garr]])âPhoebe's birth mother. Phoebe tracks her down in "The One at the Beach", believing her to be a friend of Lily's. She reveals her parentage at the end of the episode and makes amends with Phoebe in "The One with the Jellyfish". Later, when Phoebe wants to be a surrogate mother for Frank and Alice's child<ref group="e" name="Uterus"/>, she lends Phoebe her dog to demonstrate how difficult it is to give up children after carrying them.
*<span id="The Chick and The Duck"/>The '''Chick''' and the '''Duck''' ([[Animals on television|live animal actors]])âIn "The One With a Chick and a Duck.", Joey adopts a [[chicken|chick]] from an animal sanctuary, misunderstanding a news report about people who buy chicks and then find they cannot properly care for them. Encouraged by Phoebe to return the chick, but discovering that the animals would be [[animal euthanasia|euthanized]], Chandler, who went to give the chick back, returns home with the chick and a [[duck]]. Chandler and Joey treat the chick and the duck as their own children—at one point, Chandler punishes the duck by sending him out to the hall ("You stay out here and think about what you did!").
:Chandler briefly names the chick "'''Yasmine'''", after ''[[Baywatch]]'' actress [[Yasmine Bleeth]] (the chick later, however, turns out to be a rooster, not a hen); and in "The One With Ross's Thing", Chandler refers to the possible offspring of the duck and the chick as "'''Dick'''" (Joey refers to it as Chuck). By Season 6 the animals disappeared; the duck was mentioned but not seen in Season 7. In the final episode, Joey bought Chandler a new [[duckling]] and chick as a housewarming gift, which Joey names "'''Duck Jr.'''" and "'''Chick Jr.'''", and it is revealed that the birds died a while ago, and Chandler, not wanting Joey to be upset about it, told him that they had gone to live on a farm, where visitors were not allowed. The birds do not appear on the ''Friends'' spinoff ''[[Joey (sitcom)|Joey]]''.
*'''Tommy''' ([[Ben Stiller]])âone of Rachel's dates, who Ross overhears yelling loudly whenever angered. Tommy never does it in front of anybody else, causing Ross' friends not to believe him, until Tommy is caught yelling at the Chick and the Duck by everyone.{{Issue|date=November 2011}}
=== Introduced in season four === *{{anchor|Kathy}}'''Kathy''' ([[Paget Brewster]])âJoey's girlfriend, introduced in "The One with Joey's New Girlfriend" (airdate October 30, 1997; Season 4, No. 5), with whom he has nothing in common apart from both being actors. A mutual attraction develops between Kathy and Chandler<ref group="e" name="Dirty Girl"/>, which manifests as a kiss in "The One Where Chandler Crosses the Line" (November 13, 1997; Season 4, No. 7); after Joey finds out, Kathy decides to leave New York for Chicago, and declares her love to Chandler<ref group="e" name="ChandlerInBox">{{cite episode |title= The One with Chandler in a Box|credits= |airdate=1997 |season=4 |number=8 }}</ref>. Initially outraged at Chandler's betrayal, Joey has a change of heart after Kathy's speech, and she and Chandler get together. She sleeps with a co-star in "The One with Rachel's Crush" (airdate January 29, 1998; Season 4, No. 13) and Chandler dumps her.
:When Paget Brewster arrived for her audition, she believed she was the "runty alternate" and did not have a chance of getting the part. Matthew Perry later told her that the producers knew she was right for the role when she called herself a "runt". She spent her first two weeks working on the show believing that she would be fired and the part recast with a better looking actress. Brewster did not want Kathy to be written out by cheating on Chandler. The female stars agreed with her and tried to persuade the producers to have Kathy tour in a play instead.<ref>Brewster, Paget (2004). ''Friends of Friends'' [DVD]. New Wave Entertainment DVD and Warner Home Entertainment.</ref>
*'''[[Charlton Heston]]''' (himself)âis in a movie with Joey. Joey reeks from spending a day fishing without showering after, so he uses Heston's showerâonly to be caught by Heston. Joey tries to explain that he "stinks"âwhich Heston infers to refer to his acting, not his smellâand Heston gives Joey an actor's pep talk before telling him that "no matter how badly you ''think'' you stink, you must ''never'' break into ''my dressing room'' and use ''my shower!''"<ref group="e" name="Dirty Day">{{cite episode | title = The One with Joey's Dirty Day | credits = | airdate = February 5, 1998 | season = 4 | number = 14}}</ref>
*'''Cheryl''' ([[Rebecca Romjin]])âa woman Ross dates, only to find that she deliberately keeps her apartment unkempt.<ref group = "e" name = "Dirty Girl">{{cite episode | title = The One with the Dirty Girl | credits = | airdate = November 6, 1997 | season = 4 | number = 6}}</ref>
*{{anchor|Stu}}'''Stuart "Stu"''' ([[Fred Stoller]])âA waiter at Allesandro's, where Monica gets a job in "The One Where They're Going to Party!". In "The One with the Girl from Poughkeepsie" (airdate December 19, 1997; Season 4, No. 10), Stu leads a kitchen staff rebellion against Monica, locking her in a cold storage room and writing insults on her chef's hat. Monica hires Joey as a stooge so she can show her authority in front of the staff by firing him, and the rebellion soon ends. In "The One with the Stripper"<ref group="e" name="Stripper"/>, Stu gives Monica the phone number of someone she assumes is a stripper for Chandler's belated bachelor party, though she turns out to be a prostitute. [[File:TateDonovan.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Tate Donovan]] recurred as Rachel's boyfriend Joshua at the same time as he was dating Jennifer Aniston.]]
*{{anchor|Joshua Bergin}}'''Joshua Bergin''' ([[Tate Donovan]])âA recently-divorced customer who regularly uses Rachel as a personal shopper at Bloomingdale's. They start dating but break up in "The One with All the Wedding Dresses" (airdate April 16, 1998; Season 4, No. 20) when he thinks the relationship is moving too fast. Joshua appeared at the same time that Jennifer Aniston and Tate Donovan were dating each other in real life.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://media.www.redandblack.com/media/storage/paper871/news/1998/01/29/UndefinedSection/Untitled.Article-2584760.shtml |title=? |author= |date= |work= |publisher= |accessdate= }}</ref>
*{{anchor|Chip Matthews}}'''Chip Matthews''' ([[Dan Gauthier]])âChip was previously mentioned in "[[The One with the Prom Video]]" (airdate February 1, 1996; Season 2, No. 14), as Rachel's senior prom date. In this episode he was played by an unknown, uncredited actor and his face was not seen on screen. He fully appeared in the episode "The One with the Cat" (airdate October 2, 1997; Season 4, No. 2). Chip was the most popular guy in Ross, Rachel and Monica's high school, and briefly dated Rachel, until he abandoned her at their senior prom to have sex with Amy Welch. Monica and Chip meet again and Chip asked her out. Whilst Monica was delighted that her high school crush was taking her out, Rachel reacted somewhat coldly to Chip upon meeting him again, but allowed Monica to date him, as in high school she had always been saddened that Chip would never date her due to her obesity. When he asks for Monica, Rachel says, "So Chip, how's Amy Welch?", to which he replies, "Amy Welch? Wow, I haven't seen her since..." Monica's dream is soon shattered when she realizes that Chip is an immature loser who's done nothing to better himself since high school and still lives with his parents. She finds happiness in the fact that she was able to ''dump'' him afterward.
*{{anchor|Mr. Waltham}}'''Mr. Waltham''' ([[Paxton Whitehead]])âRachel's boss in season 4, who appears in "The One with Rachel's Crush" and "The One with Joey's Dirty Day".
*{{anchor|Emily Waltham}}'''Emily Waltham''' ([[Helen Baxendale]])âMr. Waltham's niece, who arrives for a two-week visit to New York in "The One with Joey's Dirty Day". She has a whirlwind romance with Ross and they decide to get married. The friends fly to London for their wedding in "The One with Ross's Wedding" (airdate May 7, 1998; Season 4, No. 23 & 24), and Ross accidentally says Rachel's name at the altar, humiliating Emily in front of her friends and family. She aims to reconcile with him at the airport in "The One After Ross Says 'Rachel'" (airdate September 24, 1998; Season 5, No. 1) but sees Rachel with him and storms out again. Ross tries to convince her to move to New York<ref group="e" name="pbs">{{cite episode|title=The One Where Phoebe Hates PBS|credits=|airdate=October 15, 1998|season=5|number=4}}</ref>. She agrees but makes him promise to get rid of "everything Rachel has ever touched", and she demands that he never see Rachel again. When she learns that he's having dinner with the old gangâincluding Rachelâshe tells him she can't trust him and she decides to end the marriage. She makes a final voice cameo in "The One with the Ride Along"<ref group="e" name="Ride-Along"/>, when she leaves a message on Ross's answering machine the night before her new wedding, telling him she is having second thoughts about it and is worried that they made a mistake splitting up. Rachel accidentally deletes the message, but tells Ross about it and convinces him not to respond to it. Emily's surname is that of the city where both creators of the show attended college.
:[[Patsy Kensit]] was originally approached to play the role but turned it down.<ref>{{cite news|author=Russo, Tom|date=April 10, 1998|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,282615,00.html|title=Her Best 'Friends' Wedding? |work=Entertainment Weekly|issue=426}}</ref> Emily and Ross' marriage was intended to last much longer in the series, but Helen Baxendale became pregnant prior to Season 5 and was unable to travel for the show; hence, her limited appearances after Season 4.<ref name="dvd">{{cite video |people=[[Kevin S. Bright|Bright, Kevin S.]]; [[Marta Kauffman]]; [[David Crane (writer/producer)|David Crane]] |date=2004|title=Friends: The Complete Fourth Season DVD audio commentary for "The One with Ross's Wedding" |medium=DVD |location=[[Los Angeles, California]] |publisher=Warner Home Video}}</ref> Helen Baxendale was asked to reprise the role in Season 10, but turned it down to star in the West End play ''[[After Miss Julie]]'', and because she did not want the same level of tabloid attention she received in 1998.<ref>{{cite news|author=Brockes, Emma|date=28 November 2003|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/stage/2003/nov/28/theatre2|title='I don't feel like a drip'|work=The Guardian|accessdate=7 July 2009}}</ref>
*{{anchors|Stephen Waltham|Andrea Waltham}}'''Stephen''' and '''Andrea Waltham''' ([[Tom Conti]] and [[Jennifer Saunders]])âEmily's father and shrewish stepmother, introduced in "The One with Ross's Wedding, Part 2". Their marriage is icy and they openly treat one another with disdain. They are equally hostile towards Jack and Judy Geller when the Gellers refuse to pay for their house to be remodelled after the wedding reception. In "The One After Ross Says 'Rachel'", Stephen tells Ross that Emily is humiliated after the wedding, and Andrea tells Ross she thinks he is "delicious".
*{{anchor|Dr. Tim Burke}}'''Dr. Tim Burke''' ([[Michael Vartan]])âMonica who had an ice chip in her eye while taking out the turkey from the freezer, meets cute Dr. Tim, son of Dr. Richard Burke ([[Tom Selleck]]). He is invited to share the Thanksgiving dinner in "The One With Chandler In A Box"<ref group="e" name="ChandlerInBox">{{cite episode |title= The One with Chandler in a Box|credits= |airdate=1997 |season=4 |number=8 }}</ref>.<ref>url=http://www.friends-tv.org/zz408.html</ref>
=== Introduced in season five === *{{anchor|Danny}}'''Daniel "Danny"''' ([[George Newbern]])âA man who has been on an around-the-world trip and returns in "The One with the Yeti".<ref group="e" name="Yeti">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Yeti|credits= |airdate=November 5, 1998 |season=5 |number=6 }}</ref> Rachel and Monica encounter the bearded man in the basement of their building and think he is a [[Yeti]]. Rachel is attracted to him but plays hard-to-get by pretending not to be interested in a housewarming party he is throwing.<ref group="e" name="RossMoves">{{cite episode |title= The One Where Ross Moves In|credits= |airdate=November 12, 1998 |season=5 |number=7 }}</ref> They eventually get together, but Rachel dumps him when she discovers he has a "special bond" with his sister.<ref group="e" name="Danny's Sister">{{cite episode |title= The One with the Inappropriate Sister|credits= |airdate=December 17, 1998 |season=5 |number=10 }}</ref>
*'''Katie''' ([[Soleil Moon Frye]])âdates Joey in "The One with the Girl Who Hits Joey". As the episode name suggests, she' a woman whose play-punches are all-too hard.<ref group="e" name="Hits Joey">{{cite episode |title=The One with the Girl Who Hits Joey|credits= |airdate=February 18, 1999|season=5|number=15}}</ref>
*{{anchor|Dr. Ledbetter}}'''Dr. Ledbetter''' ([[Michael Ensign]])âRoss's boss at the museum. After he eats Ross's leftover Thanksgiving turkey sandwich in "The One with Ross's Sandwich", Ross angrily shouts at him, and he puts Ross on sabbatical.<ref group="e" name="Sandwich">{{cite episode |title= The One with Ross's Sandwich|credits= |airdate=December 10, 1998 |season=5 |number=9 }}</ref> He reappears in the tag scene of "The One Where Everybody Finds Out".<ref group="e" name="Everybody">{{cite episode |title= The One Where Everybody Finds Out|credits= |airdate=February 11, 1999 |season=5 |number=14 }}</ref>
*{{anchor|Gary}}'''Gary''' ([[Michael Rapaport]])âA cop who accidentally leaves his badge in Central Perk.<ref group="e" name="Cop">{{cite episode |title=The One with the Cop|credits= |airdate=February 25, 1999 |season=5 |number=16 }}</ref> Phoebe finds it and starts impersonating a police officer. He tracks her down and asks her out to dinner, and they start dating. He takes Ross, Joey and Chandler on a ride-along,<ref group="e" name="Ride-Along">{{cite episode |title=The One with the Ride-Along|credits= |airdate=April 29, 1999 |season=5 |number=20 }}</ref> and asks Phoebe to move in with him.<ref group="e" name="Ball">{{cite episode |title=The One with the Ball|credits= |airdate=May 6, 1999 |season=5 |number=21 }}</ref> She leaves him after he shoots a bird.
*{{anchor|Mr. Zelner}}'''Mr. Zelner''' (Steve Ireland)âAn executive at Polo Ralph Lauren, who interviews Rachel in "The One with Rachel's Inadvertent Kiss".<ref group="e" name="Inadvertent">{{cite episode |title=The One with Rachel's Inadvertent Kiss|credits= |airdate=March 18, 1999 |season=5 |number=17 }}</ref> After Rachel is promoted in Season 7, he becomes a recurring character. In "The One with Princess Consuela", he fires Rachel after overhearing her interview with a Gucci representative.<ref group="e" name="Consuela">{{cite episode |title=The One with Princess Consuela|credits= |airdate=February 26, 2004 |season=10 |number=14 }}</ref> Ross tries to get her her job back by bribing Zelner: Zelner has a son called Ross who likes dinosaurs. Ross says his name is "Ron", shocked to hear that Zelner's son is called Ross. <ref group="e" name="Estelle">{{cite episode |title=The One Where Estelle Dies|credits= |airdate=April 22, 2004 |season=10 |number=15 }}</ref>
*{{anchor|Kim}}'''Kim''' ([[Joanna Gleason]])âA co-worker of Rachel's at Polo Ralph Lauren. In "The One Where Rachel Smokes", Rachel thinks she is missing out on important decisions, as they are always made when Kim goes on a smoking break. She tries to take up smoking so she can stay in the loop but is unsuccessful when Kim threatens to fire her if she keeps damaging her health.<ref group="e" name="Smokes">{{cite episode |title=The One Where Rachel Smokes|credits= |airdate=April 8, 1999 |season=5 |number=18 }}</ref> Later, Kim thinks Rachel kissed [[Ralph Lauren]] in order to take her job, when it was really Phoebe who kissed "Kenny the copy guy". After unsuccessfully trying to deny the affair, Rachel pretends Ralph dumped her. Kim believes her when she sees what she thinks is a cold look from Ralph (appearing as himself) in the elevator.<ref group="e" name="Teeth">{{cite episode |title=The One with Ross's Teeth|credits= |airdate=November 18, 1999 |season=6 |number=8 }}</ref>
=== Introduced in season six === *{{anchor|Janine LaCroix}}'''Janine LaCroix''' ([[Elle Macpherson]])âAfter Chandler moves in with Monica, Joey places an ad for a new roommate in "The One Where Phoebe Runs". Attractive Australian dancer Janine applies and Joey immediately gives her the room without knowing anything else about her.<ref group="e" name="PhoebeRuns">{{cite episode |title=The One Where Phoebe Runs|credits= |airdate=November 11, 1999|season=6 |number=7 }}</ref> She adds a feminine touch to the apartment by hanging pictures of babies, flowers, and babies dressed as flowers, which unnerves Joeyâwho senses that he's "becoming a woman".<ref group="e" name="Teeth">{{cite episode |title=The One with Ross Teeth|credits= |airdate=November 18, 1999 |season=6 |number=8}}</ref> They get together during the recording of ''[[Dick Clark's New Year's Rockin' Eve]]'',<ref group="e" name="Routine">{{cite episode |title=The One with the Routine|credits= |airdate=December 16, 1999 |season=6 |number=10 }}</ref> but break up after she reveals she does not like Monica and Chandler. She moves out soon after.<ref group="e" name="Apothecary">{{cite episode |title=The One with Apothecary Table|credits= |airdate=January 6, 2000|season=6 |number=11}}</ref>
*'''The Judge''' ([[Conchata Ferrell]])âRoss and Rachelâwho got married in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]] while drunkâgo to her to get an annullment, only to find that they have to get a divorce instead.<ref group="e" name="Porsche">{{cite episode | title = The One with Joey's Porsche | credits = | airdate = October 21, 1999 | season = 6 | number = 5}}</ref>
*{{anchor|Jill Green}}'''Jill Green''' ([[Reese Witherspoon]])âOne of Rachel's two sisters, who arrives at Monica and Chandler's in "The One with Rachel's Sister", thinking Rachel still lives there. Their father has cut off Jill's supply of money and sent her to stay with Rachel, "the only daughter he's ever been proud of."
